question.content: From http://xkcd.com/blue_eyes.html Blue Eyes: The Hardest Logic Puzzle in the WorldA group of people with assorted eye colors live on an island. They are all perfect logicians -- if a conclusion can be logically deduced, they will do it instantly. No one knows the color of their eyes. Every night at midnight, a ferry stops at the island. Any islanders who have figured out the color of their own eyes then leave the island, and the rest stay. Everyone can see everyone else at all times and keeps a count of the number of people they see with each eye color (excluding themselves), but they cannot otherwise communicate. Everyone on the island knows all the rules in this paragraph. On this island there are 100 blue-eyed people, 100 brown-eyed people, and the Guru (she happens to have green eyes). So any given blue-eyed person can see 100 people with brown eyes and 99 people with blue eyes (and one with green), but that does not tell him his own eye color; as far as he knows the totals could be 101 brown and 99 blue. Or 100 brown, 99 blue, and he could have red eyes. The Guru is allowed to speak once (let's say at noon), on one day in all their endless years on the island. Standing before the islanders, she says the following: "I can see someone who has blue eyes." Who leaves the island, and on what night? There are no mirrors or reflecting surfaces, nothing dumb. It is not a trick question, and the answer is logical. It doesn't depend on tricky wording or anyone lying or guessing, and it doesn't involve people doing something silly like creating a sign language or doing genetics. The Guru is not making eye contact with anyone in particular; she's simply saying "I count at least one blue-eyed person on this island who isn't me." And lastly, the answer is not "no one leaves." ---------------- Terry Tao discusses a much more vicious version:  There is an island upon which a tribe resides. The tribe consists of 1000 people, with various eye colours. Yet, their religion forbids them to know their own eye color, or even to discuss the topic; thus, each resident can (and does) see the eye colors of all other residents, but has no way of discovering his or her own (there are no reflective surfaces). If a tribesperson does discover his or her own eye color, then their religion compels them to commit ritual suicide at noon the following day in the village square for all to witness. All the tribespeople are highly logical and devout, and they all know that each other is also highly logical and devout (and they all know that they all know that each other is highly logical and devout, and so forth).  ["Highly logical" means that any conclusion that can logically deduced from the information and observations available to an islander, will automatically be known to that islander.] Of the 1000 islanders, it turns out that 100 of them have blue eyes and 900 of them have brown eyes, although the islanders are not initially aware of these statistics (each of them can of course only see 999 of the 1000 tribespeople). One day, a blue-eyed foreigner visits to the island and wins the complete trust of the tribe. One evening, he addresses the entire tribe to thank them for their hospitality. However, not knowing the customs, the foreigner makes the mistake of mentioning eye color in his address, remarking “how unusual it is to see another blue-eyed person like myself in this region of the world”. What effect, if anything, does this faux pas have on the tribe?

question.content: In a group of n people, a celebrity is a person who everyone else knows, but who doesn't know anyone else. Lets write [latex]aKb[/latex] iff a knows b, and [latex]a ot!! K b[/latex] iff a does not know b.  So [latex]cin[1..n][/latex] is a celebrity iff [latex]forall ain[1..n],; (a=c)vee (aKcwedge c ot!!Ka)[/latex].  Can a group have more than one celebrity? A simple substitution cypher replaces each letter a-z with some other letter in an invertible manner -- it is a bijection from a-z to a-z. You may have seen Cryptoquote in the newspaper, for which the standard example is AXYDLBAAXR = LONGFELLOW (i.e., a-> L and x-> O.)

How many different simple substitution cyphers are there?

Suppose that we want to avoid sending a letter to itself, so we replace letters from the first half (a-m) with letters from the second half (n-z) and vice versa. With this restriction, how many different simple substitution cyphers are there?

Counting the number of substitution cyphers in which no letter maps to itself is not easy, but you can take a swing at that, too.

`Change ringing'  is a peculiarly British pastime of ringing church bells (or handbells) to do all mathematical permutations: e.g., if you had three bells, numbered from highest to lowest, you might ring the patterns 123, 213, 231, 321, 312, 132, 123, where the only repeat is the start and ending pattern, which is the descending bell sequence called rounds.  (This would be a full peal, if the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers would admit peals of less than 4 bells.)

Suppose each pattern or change takes 2 seconds.  How long would it take to do a full peal with 4, 5, 6, 7, or 8 bells?

For the musicians: How many choices do you have when making a musical composition?  There are many things that make this question hard (types of instruments, tonal scale, time signature, dynamic range, tempo, chords, rests, slurs, holds, glissandos, ...)  Let's start with simple versions of this question.

Let's say we want to compose an 8-measure theme in 4/4 time, and let ourselves use whole, half, quarter, eighth, and sixteenth notes.  Ignore dynamic range and tempo changes, and fancy trills, slides, etc.  Even for the following simpler questions the answers will not be easy to count.

In fact, let's start with a single tone (middle-C) no rests.  How many different patterns of notes can you have in a single measure?  In eight measures?

 

Now, add the choice of tone for each note (still no rests) .  What expression counts if you can choose your notes from, say, the 88 keys on a piano?

 

If you add rests, observe that consecutive rests (unlike notes of the same tone) may merge into a longer rest. Can we add those to the count?

 

What other variants would you like to count?

In cribbage, you are dealt six cards and can choose two to discard. Then there is one more card turned over.  At the end of a round of play, you count points from that five-card hand.   Here are four questions for counting cribbage hands; pick one to answer and refer to the number.

  1. How many possibilities do you have to choose the two cards to discard out of the six you are dealt?
  2. You get two points for each pair of cards with the same number.  How many pairs are are there if you have three 5s?  How many if you have four 5s?
  3. You also get two points for each combination that adds up to 15.  How many points (from pairs and 15s) do you get if you have four 5s in your hand, and a 10 was turned over?
  4. You also get three points for each run of three cards, such as 4,5,6 of any suit.  How many points (runs, 15s, pairs) do you get from 4♦,4♥,5♦,6♣,6♠?

question.title: Induction 37: Can you show this property of digit sums?
question.content:
Let's define the repeated digit sum, or RDS(n) as the function that sends natural numbers to [0..9] by summing their digits in base 10 repeatedly until the result is in [0..9]. That is, RDS(1) = 1, RDS(11) = 2, RDS(1234) = RDS(10) = 1.
We could write a recursive definition of this function, if that would make it more clear:
Base: for a single digit d in [0..9], RDS(d) = d.
Rec rule: for an integer written in decimal with k>1 digits, d=d<sub>k</sub>d<sub>k-1</sub>...d<sub>1</sub>d<sub>0</sub>, RDS(d)=RDS(d<sub>k</sub>+d<sub>k-1</sub>+...+d<sub>1</sub>+d<sub>0</sub>). OR, avoiding the ellipses: for an integer written in decimal with k>1 digits, [latex]d=sum_{0le i le k} d_i10^i[/latex], RDS(d)=RDS([latex]sum_{0le i le k} d_i[/latex]).
Prove that for all [latex]a,bin mathbb{N}[/latex], RDS(a*b) = RDS(RDS(a)*RDS(b)).

question.title: Show that irrational numbers behave irrationally, in the sense that their fractional parts show up all over the real interval [0,1]?
question.content:
A mathematical example to prove:  For these questions, let [x] denote the fractional part of x: that is, $latex {[x]=x-lfloor x floor}$. We are going to look at the set of all fractional parts, $latex {F_{alpha}={[na]midforall nin I!!N}}$.  Recall that a number $latex alpha$ is irrational iff there do not exist integers $latex p,q$ satisfying $latex {alpha=p/q}$.  Show the following:
  1. For any irrational number $latex alpha$, the elements we put into set $latex {F_{alpha}}$ are distinct. That is, for all positive integers $latex m,nin I!!N$, we have $latex {[malpha]=[nalpha]}$ iff $latex m=n$.
  2. For any irrational number $latex alpha$, the lower limit $latex inf F_{alpha} = 0$. That is, for any $latex epsilon>0$, there is an $latex nin I!!N$ with $latex [nalpha]<epsilon$.  (Hint:  Use pigeonhole principle to show that two fractional parts must be close, then subtract them.)
  3. For any irrational number $latex alpha$, the set $latex F_{alpha}$ is df{dense} in the interval $latex [0,1]$. That is, for any reals $latex {xin[0,1]}$ and $latex epsilon>0$, there is an $latex nin I!!N$ such that $latex {|x-[nalpha]|<epsilon}$.
One way to generate pseudo-random numbers is to take the fractional parts of integer multiples of an irrational number.

question.title: Induction 39: Can you determine who is a celebrity, if any, with few questions?

K b[/latex] iff a does not know b.  So [latex]cin[1..n][/latex] is a celebrity iff [latex]forall ain[1..n],; (a=c)vee (aKcwedge c ot!!Ka)[/latex].  Can a group have more than one celebrity? You are an outsider, sent by a news agency, to identify if there is a celebrity at a party of n people.  You want to ask people if they know specific other people, but don't want to annoy and get kicked out, so you want to ask few questions.   There are, of course, (n-1) possible questions per person, for a total of n(n-1).  How few questions do you need to ask to guarantee that you can always identify and confirm the identity of a celebrity, if one exists?  (You cannot ask one person "Do you know anyone here?' without asking them n-1 questions, which is sure to get you kicked out.) question.title: Induction 25: How will the oldest pirate propose to split the coins?

Ten pirates are going to split 100 coins. The pirates have a strict seniority.   2. Does the proposal change if the proposer is not allowed to vote? (That is, if the proposal needs a strict majority to accept?)

question.title: Questions about the game SET
question.content:
Here are four questions about the card game SET.

(B) Symbol: Each card contains ovals, squiggles, or diamonds.

question.title: Induction 31; Can you represent numbers as sets?

question.title: More Induction Practice! (more challenging)
question.content: This was the problem I alluded to in Induction25: Suppose for some n≥2 that n children are given a large vat of holiday cookie dough to divide amongst themselves. The children do not trust one another; each is convinced that the other n-1 are out to steal more than their fair share. Prove by induction on n that under the following division procedure, each child will leave the bargaining table convinced that he or she has not been shortchanged on cookie dough.   First, one child selects what he or she believes to be exactly an nth of the cookie dough. The remaining children are then given the opportunity, one at a time, to inspect this portion. If a child perceives it to be no more than an nth of the entire batch, it passes to the next child for inspection. Otherwise, this child shaves off whatever he or she deems to be the excessive amount, returns the extra dough to the vat, and claims the remainder as his or her portion. This portion is then inspected by the next child. The inspection process continues, with the portion changing hands and being reduced whenever it is perceived to be unfairly large, until all children have had the opportunity to examine it. At this time, whoever is in possession of the dough portion devours it and leaves the room. The n-1 children who are left then repeat the procedure: One child selects what he or she believes to be an (n-1)st of what is left in the vat and another round of inspections begins, at the end of which one child devours a hunk of dough and departs. The process continues until all but one child have left the room, at which point the remaining child consumes what is left in the vat.

question.title: Induction 36: What happens to the islanders?
question.content: From http://xkcd.com/blue_eyes.html Blue Eyes: The Hardest Logic Puzzle in the WorldA group of people with assorted eye colors live on an island. They are all perfect logicians -- if a conclusion can be logically deduced, they will do it instantly. No one knows the color of their eyes. Every night at midnight, a ferry stops at the island. Any islanders who have figured out the color of their own eyes then leave the island, and the rest stay. Everyone can see everyone else at all times and keeps a count of the number of people they see with each eye color (excluding themselves), but they cannot otherwise communicate. Everyone on the island knows all the rules in this paragraph. On this island there are 100 blue-eyed people, 100 brown-eyed people, and the Guru (she happens to have green eyes). So any given blue-eyed person can see 100 people with brown eyes and 99 people with blue eyes (and one with green), but that does not tell him his own eye color; as far as he knows the totals could be 101 brown and 99 blue. Or 100 brown, 99 blue, and he could have red eyes. The Guru is allowed to speak once (let's say at noon), on one day in all their endless years on the island. Standing before the islanders, she says the following: "I can see someone who has blue eyes." Who leaves the island, and on what night? There are no mirrors or reflecting surfaces, nothing dumb. It is not a trick question, and the answer is logical. It doesn't depend on tricky wording or anyone lying or guessing, and it doesn't involve people doing something silly like creating a sign language or doing genetics. The Guru is not making eye contact with anyone in particular; she's simply saying "I count at least one blue-eyed person on this island who isn't me." And lastly, the answer is not "no one leaves." ---------------- Terry Tao discusses a much more vicious version:  There is an island upon which a tribe resides. The tribe consists of 1000 people, with various eye colours. Yet, their religion forbids them to know their own eye color, or even to discuss the topic; thus, each resident can (and does) see the eye colors of all other residents, but has no way of discovering his or her own (there are no reflective surfaces). If a tribesperson does discover his or her own eye color, then their religion compels them to commit ritual suicide at noon the following day in the village square for all to witness. All the tribespeople are highly logical and devout, and they all know that each other is also highly logical and devout (and they all know that they all know that each other is highly logical and devout, and so forth).  ["Highly logical" means that any conclusion that can logically deduced from the information and observations available to an islander, will automatically be known to that islander.] Of the 1000 islanders, it turns out that 100 of them have blue eyes and 900 of them have brown eyes, although the islanders are not initially aware of these statistics (each of them can of course only see 999 of the 1000 tribespeople). One day, a blue-eyed foreigner visits to the island and wins the complete trust of the tribe. One evening, he addresses the entire tribe to thank them for their hospitality. However, not knowing the customs, the foreigner makes the mistake of mentioning eye color in his address, remarking “how unusual it is to see another blue-eyed person like myself in this region of the world”. What effect, if anything, does this faux pas have on the tribe?

question.title: How many orders of n people in a circle to play a game?
question.content:
From activity games to card games, to board games, you often arrange players in a circle.  Sometimes the capability or personalities of the players to your left or right (or both) make a difference in your chances to win the game (You've perhaps played with the "forgetful trumper" who thought they were discarding, or the "vengeful Uno opponent" who keeps calling for someone to play a reverse after you've dumped a wild draw four on them...)

  1. How many different orders are there for n players?  Two orders are considered the same  if and only if every player has the same player to the right .
  2. What if the players come in couples that want to sit next to each other?  Now how many orders?
  3. What if couples never want to sit next to each other (as they should in Uno).  Can you now count how many orders?

question.title: Can you convert quantified expressions to English statements and vice versa?
question.content:
Let $latex D$ be the set of all dorms on campus.

 

Let $latex P$ be the set of all people, $latex lcolon P imes D o {T,F}$ be the predicate such that $latex l(p,d)$ is true iff $latex p in P$ lives in dorm $latex din D$.
Let $latex deltacolon P o P$ be the predicate such that $latex delta(p,q)$ iff $latex pin P$ has dated $latex qin P$.

 

What are the English meanings of the following?

  1. $latex exists pin P$, $latex forall qin P$, $latex overline{d(p,q)}$.
  2. $latex forall pin P$, [latex] exists qin P[/latex], $latex overline{d(p,q)}$.
  3. $latex { otexists pin P,}$, $latex forall qin P,$ $latex d(p,q)$.
  4. $latex exists pin P$, $latex {forall din D}$,   $latex exists qin P$ $latex d(p,q) wedge l(q,d)$.
  5. $latex forall c,din D$,  $latex exists x,yin P$ ,  $latex {l(x,c)wedge l(y,d) wedge d(x,y)}$.
  6. $latex forall din D$, $latex {exists pin P}$,   $latex {forall q in P}$,  $latex {l(p,d) wedge l(q,d) wedge d(p,q)}$

 

What quantified statements represent these English sentences?

  1. Noone has dated themselves.
  2. Noone has dated anyone.
  3. Someone has dated every resident from some dorm.
  4. There is a dorm in which every resident has dated someone.
  5. There is a dorm whose residents have not dated anyone from
    another dorm.
  6. There are two people who, between the two of them, have dated
    someone from every dorm.

question.title: How many simple substitution cyphers on [a-z]?
question.content:
A simple substitution cypher replaces each letter a-z with some other letter in an invertible manner -- it is a bijection from a-z to a-z. You may have seen Cryptoquote in the newspaper, for which the standard example is AXYDLBAAXR = LONGFELLOW (i.e., a-> L and x-> O.)

How many different simple substitution cyphers are there?

Suppose that we want to avoid sending a letter to itself, so we replace letters from the first half (a-m) with letters from the second half (n-z) and vice versa. With this restriction, how many different simple substitution cyphers are there?

Counting the number of substitution cyphers in which no letter maps to itself is not easy, but you can take a swing at that, too.

question.title: How long does it take to do a full peal for change ringing n bells?
question.content:
`Change ringing'  is a peculiarly British pastime of ringing church bells (or handbells) to do all mathematical permutations: e.g., if you had three bells, numbered from highest to lowest, you might ring the patterns 123, 213, 231, 321, 312, 132, 123, where the only repeat is the start and ending pattern, which is the descending bell sequence called rounds.  (This would be a full peal, if the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers would admit peals of less than 4 bells.)

Suppose each pattern or change takes 2 seconds.  How long would it take to do a full peal with 4, 5, 6, 7, or 8 bells?

question.title: How many musical compositions are there?
question.content:
For the musicians: How many choices do you have when making a musical composition?  There are many things that make this question hard (types of instruments, tonal scale, time signature, dynamic range, tempo, chords, rests, slurs, holds, glissandos, ...)  Let's start with simple versions of this question.

Let's say we want to compose an 8-measure theme in 4/4 time, and let ourselves use whole, half, quarter, eighth, and sixteenth notes.  Ignore dynamic range and tempo changes, and fancy trills, slides, etc.  Even for the following simpler questions the answers will not be easy to count.

In fact, let's start with a single tone (middle-C) no rests.  How many different patterns of notes can you have in a single measure?  In eight measures?

 

Now, add the choice of tone for each note (still no rests) .  What expression counts if you can choose your notes from, say, the 88 keys on a piano?

 

If you add rests, observe that consecutive rests (unlike notes of the same tone) may merge into a longer rest. Can we add those to the count?

 

What other variants would you like to count?

question.title: How many combinations on a single-dial padlock?
question.content:
A common single dial padlock has numbers 1-40, and a combination of three of these.  How many combinations does it have?

Since you can test all third digits with a single slow turn, how many combinations are there of the first two digits?

Often it is enough to hit the first and second digit to within $latex pm2$.  In that case, how many "slow turns" do you need to do to open a lock with unknown combination?

question.title: How many pages in Sol Lewitt's portfolio?
question.content:
Artist Sol Lewitt did a
series of one-page etchings in 1973 entitled Straight lines in four directions and all their possible combinations. The lines are the ways to fold a square in half.  You can see the cover of the portfolio here.  How many pages should he have had in his portfolio?

Can you arrange the pages to form a larger square so that lines end only at the edges of the larger square?  (In the arrangement linked above you can find horizontal, vertical, and diagonal lines that don't continue from edge to edge, but end in the middle.)

question.title: How many cribbage hands?
question.content:
In cribbage, you are dealt six cards and can choose two to discard. Then there is one more card turned over.  At the end of a round of play, you count points from that five-card hand.   Here are four questions for counting cribbage hands; pick one to answer and refer to the number.

  1. How many possibilities do you have to choose the two cards to discard out of the six you are dealt?
  2. You get two points for each pair of cards with the same number.  How many pairs are are there if you have three 5s?  How many if you have four 5s?
  3. You also get two points for each combination that adds up to 15.  How many points (from pairs and 15s) do you get if you have four 5s in your hand, and a 10 was turned over?
  4. You also get three points for each run of three cards, such as 4,5,6 of any suit.  How many points (runs, 15s, pairs) do you get from 4♦,4♥,5♦,6♣,6♠?

question.title: How many ways to board the bus?
question.content:
Supposed that three girls and four boys line up to board a school bus.

a. In how many ways can the seven children line up?

b. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are the three girls first in line?

c. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are the three girls together in line?

d. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are the four boys together in line?

e. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are no two boys together?

You have objects of n colors and are making a k-tuple, so order matters and you can repeat a color.  We know how many ways that can be done.

Use this definition to show the following for all integers a,b,c.

  1. If $latex a| b$ and $latex b| c$, then $latex a| c$.
  2. If $latex a| b$ then $latex ac| bc$.
  3. If $latex a| b$ and $latex b e 0$ then $latex |a|le |b|$.
  4. If $latex a| b$ and $latex b| a$ then $latex |a|=|b|$.
  5. If $latex a| b$ and $latex a e 0$ then $latex b/a$ is an integer.
  6. Assume that $latex a> 0$.  We have $latex bmod a =c mod a$ iff $latex a| (b-c)$.
